Articles.Content: Somehow I doubt that the Mohole is a bug due to its presence ever since .17 at least. But some people still claim its a bug. I just wanted to say that its probably not a bug due to not being fixed when its really an easy fix comparatively. Squad tweaks the heightmaps every version so if it were a bug wouldn't it be fixed? Just saying my opinion here, How about you now say your's?

In my opinion it is not a bug.

Removing moholes would be like removing SRB's.

They are part of KSP.

Remooving Munholes would be a pity too.

They make good practice moholes.

Same with pointy poles, mountainous poles are really dramatic places.

I think it originally was caused by a bug, but it adds something interesting, people like it, so it's now a feature. If Squad removed it, people would be pretty mad, and what's the point or removing it, so there can be a flat patch of ground, that would just take away something fun about the game, one less place of interest to visit

I'd say it's a bug, after all, many other planets have strange pyramids at their poles. But I don't think it should be fixed, as it gives an actual reason to visit Moho. (It's the only place I have not landed on yet)

Yes, first one was probably an bug, then they keept it, note that many poles has features, Mun, Eve, Duna, Tylo even Jool the other has not, however the features are pretty similar on both poles while Moho south pole is flat.

What i would like to see is...

The terrein bugs removed. So no more Mohole.

But similar terrain features properly implemented. Meaning the addition of new, interesting and hand made holes, caves, canyons, gorges, ravines, pillars, etc.

In general planetary terrain is rather bland, I would love to see the proper implementation of interesting terrain features on all bodies.

For Moho, I think the dev's said was a bug with terrain generation, which is not an integral part of KSP. I don't have the exact source though, it was just circulating around these forums.

Unlike some games (i.e. RTS games), I don't think the terrain isn't generated by the game when KSP loads, so it isn't exactly a KSP bug. It could actually be that the polar regions of the MÃƒÂ¼n were intentionally made to be rough, though. I've recently landed some crewed missions in the polar in career mode, and there are very steep cliffs and mountains in those areas some distance from the poles. You can see the rough terrain from orbit, but determining the actual shape of the terrain usually involves powered flight with lights running. A lot of areas that far north or south are darkness, while the peaks are illuminated.
I wouldn't say it's a bug in KSP itself, but just a flaw when the terrain for each body was made.

was a bug.

was kept because it's humorous.

not all bugs need be bad things...

I think the holes were generated by a bug, then I think the developers found it as they were first testing and developing the planet, liked it and named/renamed it to Moho. Why did they name it Moho? I voted it's not a bug. It's a feature.

You know, a feature that was once a bug that the community loved so much the devs kept it as a feature. After all this time, they could've gotten rid of it, but they haven't.
As much as I want to say it's a feature, a bug is still a bug, until it's fully implemented and/or refined, it's still a bug

Starsiege: Tribes had a major physics exploit in that players would slide when they landed on the ground. A player exploited that by jumping every time they touched the ground to preserve speed. It was completely untouched by the devs and was given "feature" status when players enjoyed it.

This may easily be the same type of case.

I find it kind of silly that 58% voted for not a bug...

Its obviously a bug. The way terrain generations work, the poles are always screwed up. It was found, people liked it, so they kept it.

Bug.

It may have initially been a bug, but as it is the players are left to come up with explanations as to why there would be deep holes on a faraway world. I might not like falling into them, but they have their purpose now. Voted "no".
